Massachusetts General Laws chapter 208,.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws chapter 208, section 28, a court may modify a custody order upon a showing of a material change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Case law, including but not limited to Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) and Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 159 (2006), supports the granting of a modification to custody orders where there has been a substantial change in circumstances affecting the child's welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation and initial custody case, not a custody-modification case. The opinion interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates the “real advantage” standard and best-interests analysis for allowing a custodial parent to remove children from the Commonwealth after divorce. It does not discuss the standard for modifying existing custody orders based on a substantial change in circumstances, so it does not provide authority for the proposition about modifications of custody orders.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 159 (2006).proposition: Case law, including but not limited to Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) and Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 159 (2006), supports the granting of a modification to custody orders where there has been a substantial change in circumstances affecting the child's welfare.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 159 (2006).support_reasoning: This opinion is a tort/negligence decision about a homeowner’s duty regarding storage of firearms and has nothing to do with family law, custody, or modification of custody orders. It nowhere discusses substantial changes in circumstances, the best interests of the child, or any custody framework. Therefore, it does not support the claimed proposition about modification of custody orders.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 159 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured.”

Custody of Vaillancourt, 39 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Custody of Vaillancourt, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 211 (1995)
Custody of Vaillancourt, 39 Mass. App. C.proposition: It is well-established that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody matters, as held in numerous cases such as Custody of Vaillancourt, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 211 (1995) and Department of Children and Families v. N.D., 474 Mass. 630 (2016).
Custody of Vaillancourt, 39 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Custody of Vaillancourt concerns the statutory requirement to appoint independent counsel for children when a Probate Court contemplates awarding custody to DSS under G.L. c. 119, § 23(C). It does not discuss or articulate the general principle that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody matters. Therefore, this case, at least on the basis of the quoted text, does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
Custody of Vaillancourt, 39 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: We hold that when a Probate Court judge contemplates an award of custody of a minor child to DSS under G. L. c. 119, § 23(C), the judge must follow the mandate of G. L. c. 119, § 29, and ensure the child’s right to representation by independent counsel. We do not intimate that a child whose custody is in dispute in a divorce action has a right to counsel.

Department of Children and Families v. N.raw_text: Department of Children and Families v. N.D., 474 Mass. 630 (2016)
Department of Children and Families v. N.proposition: It is well-established that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody matters, as held in numerous cases such as Custody of Vaillancourt, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 211 (1995) and Department of Children and Families v. N.D., 474 Mass. 630 (2016).
Department of Children and Families v. N.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Department of Children and Families v. N.D., 474 Mass. 630 (2016), but Commonwealth v. Carter, a criminal case about involuntary manslaughter arising from encouraging suicide. The text contains no discussion of custody, best interests of the child, or related family-law standards. Therefore, this opinion does not support the proposition about the best interests of the child being paramount in custody matters.
Department of Children and Families v. N.relevant_excerpt: Because there is no discussion of custody or the best interests of the child in this opinion, there is no relevant excerpt supporting the claimed proposition.
